Question: A gardener wants to determine if a new fertilizer increases tomato plant growth.
She has 10 tomato seedlings of the same variety that she planted on the same day.

Design an experiment to test the effectiveness of the fertilizer, explaining what the control variables should be, what the experimental variable is, and how to set up a proper control group for comparison.

Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so the gardener wants to figure out if this new fertilizer is making her tomatoes grow bigger.
She has 10 seedlings, all the same variety, planted on the same day.
That’s a good start because it means the only difference between the plants should be the fertilizer treatment they get.
First, I need to think about what variables are involved.
The main thing she wants to measure is plant growth.
But how exactly? She could measure the height, the number of tomatoes, or the weight of the tomatoes.
Maybe all of these? It might be best to measure a few different aspects to get a comprehensive view.
Next, the control variables.
These are the things that shouldn’t change between the groups to see if the fertilizer is the only factor affecting growth.
So, the type of soil, water, sunlight, and maybe the support structure for the plants should all stay the same for each group.
If these change, it might skew the results.
The experimental variable here is the fertilizer.
She can use different concentrations or maybe different brands, but since it's a new fertilizer, maybe just the concentration.
She could have a control group that gets no fertilizer or a standard fertilizer, and the test group gets the new one.
Setting up the control group is important.
The control group should have plants that are identical to the test group in every way except for the fertilizer.
So, same soil, water, sunlight, etc.
This way, any growth differences can be attributed to the fertilizer.
For the test group, they get the new fertilizer.
She needs to apply it at the same time and in the same way as the control group to avoid any unintended variables.
After setting everything up, she should measure the plants after a certain period, maybe a few weeks after planting.
She can record the height, number of tomatoes, and maybe the weight.
Then, compare the test group to the control group.
If the test group is significantly larger, the fertilizer works.
Wait, but she has 10 plants.
Should she split them into groups? Maybe 3 groups: two test groups with different concentrations and a control.
Or maybe one test group and one control.
But with 10, maybe two test groups and a control to see if both concentrations work.
But the question just asks to design an experiment, not necessarily how many groups.
So maybe just a test group and a control.
But to be thorough, perhaps using multiple test groups with different dosages could be better.
But that might complicate things.
I think the main points are identifying the control variables, defining the experimental variable, and setting up a proper control group.
So, the key is making sure all other factors are the same except for the fertilizer.
That way, the difference in growth can be solely attributed to the fertilizer.

</think>

The gardener should design an experiment where she has two groups of tomato seedlings: one receiving the new fertilizer and the other as a control without the fertilizer.
She will ensure that all control variables such as soil type, water, sunlight, and support structure are identical for both groups.
She will measure growth by recording the height, number, and weight of the tomatoes after a set period.
The control group will serve as a baseline to compare against the test group's growth, allowing her to determine if the fertilizer effectively increases plant growth.
